Issues.Title: fix(ivy): don't track identifiers of ffr-resolved references
Issues.Body:
This fix is for a bug in the ngtsc PartialEvaluator, which statically
evaluates expressions.

Sometimes, evaluating a reference requires resolving a function which is
declared in another module, and thus no function body is available. To
support this case, the PartialEvaluator has the concept of a foreign
function resolver.

This allows the interpretation of expressions like:

const router = RouterModule.forRoot([]);

even though the definition of the 'forRoot' function has no body. In
ngtsc today, this will be resolved to a Reference to RouterModule itself,
via the ModuleWithProviders foreign function resolver.

However, the PartialEvaluator also associates any Identifiers in the path
of this resolution with the Reference. This is done so that if the user
writes

const x = imported.y;

'x' can be generated as a local identifier instead of adding an import for
'y'.

This was at the heart of a bug. In the above case with 'router', the
PartialEvaluator added the identifier 'router' to the Reference generated
(through FFR) to RouterModule.

This is not correct. References that result from FFR expressions may not
have the same value at runtime as they do at compile time (indeed, this is
not the case for ModuleWithProviders). The Reference generated via FFR is
"synthetic" in the sense that it's constructed based on a useful
interpretation of the code, not an accurate representation of the runtime
value. Therefore, it may not be legal to refer to the Reference via the
'router' identifier.

This commit adds the ability to mark such a Reference as 'synthetic', which
allows the PartialEvaluator to not add the 'router' identifier down the
line. Tests are included for both the PartialEvaluator itself as well as the
resultant buggy behavior in ngtsc overall.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "fix(ivy): don't track identifiers of ffr-resolved references" (#29387)

Issues.Title: The state passed to router.navigate is lost when doing multiple navigations
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report

### Affected Package
@angular/router

### Description
The state passed to router.navigate is lost when doing multiple navigations.

## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction
https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-nrjzxe

Pressing 'FOO' will call router.navigate with state { foo: true }.
If you press it once, you will see in the console that the resolver can see this state (via getCurrentNavigation).
If you press it multiple times quickly (the resolver takes two seconds), all but the last navigation are canceled and during the navigations past the initial one, the resolver can no longer see this state.  

I would expect to always be able to access the state from the resolver.

## üåç  Your Environment
Angular version 7.2.5
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "The state passed to router.navigate is lost when doing multiple navigations" (#29389)

Issues.Title: fix(ivy): Class selector directives execute properly on container ele‚Ä¶
Issues.Body:
‚Ä¶ments

- Adds two tests around directive execution on container elements (`<ng-container>`)
- Resolves an issue where ivy was unable to locate directives with class-based selectors if the class was on a container element.

The issue boiled down to the fact we weren't setting up a styling template for ng-container, because rendering-wise, we didn't need them. However, we *do* need them when it comes to locating directives that may exist on the container element.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(ivy): Class selector directives execute properly on container ele‚Ä¶" (#29383)

Issues.Body:

# üöÄ feature request

### Relevant Package
This feature request is for @angular/core


### Description
Today, we have four options with regards to view encapsulation in Angular: Emulated, Native, None and ShadowDom. There is usually only one reason I ever have to switch from Emulated to another option, typically None, and that's because there's styling in a third-party component that I need to override for some reason. 

However, it's annoying that I can only opt into view encapsulation as an all or nothing proposition, especially given its usefulness in simplifying my development by ensuring that I don't have colliding class names across my own various components.


### Describe the solution you'd like
It would be fantastic to have a fifth option,, one that would allow me to decorate the CSS selectors in such a way so as to indicate that I'm selectively opting out of the view-encapsulation, but only for those decorated selectors.


### Describe alternatives you've considered
I have two options I can currently take:
- Put the overriding CSS in a base file to compile into the rest of the solution
- Opt out of view encapsulation on a per-component basis

The downside to the former option is that my override file is no longer a 1:1 relationship to a given component, but now becomes a clutter of various overrides. The downside to the latter is that I usually have need for CSS customization in the component apart from the few changes I apply to the component I'm overriding, and now I have to ensure that I'm without collisions all over again. In other words, either of these alternatives are less than ideal and forgo the benefits of view encapsulation in the first place.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Partial view encapsulation" (#29364)

Issues.Title: ci: run e2e snapshots for renovate user
Issues.Body:
When a PR is opened by an upstream user, the username value will be available in `CIRCLE_PR_USERNAME` environment variable and not `CIRCLE_PROJECT_USERNAME`

```
  CIRCLE_PROJECT_REPONAME=angular-cli
  CIRCLE_PROJECT_USERNAME=angular
  CIRCLE_PR_NUMBER=13923
  CIRCLE_PR_REPONAME=angular-cli
  CIRCLE_PR_USERNAME=renovate-bot
```

see https://circleci.com/gh/angular/angular-cli/45116#tests/containers/0
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "ci: run e2e snapshots for renovate user" (#13934)

Issues.Title: Enable custom arguments in serve command
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ Feature request


### Command (mark with an `x`)
<!-- Can you pin-point the command or commands that are relevant for this feature request? -->
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏èedit: -->
```
- [ ] new
- [ ] build
- [X] serve
- [ ] test
- [ ] e2e
- [ ] generate
- [ ] add
- [ ] update
- [ ] lint
- [ ] xi18n
- [ ] run
- [ ] config
- [ ] help
- [ ] version
- [ ] doc
```

### Description
Hello, Can you please enable the custom arguments in ng serve command? I was able to pass extra args with 1.7.X builds but with new CLI versions I can't simply because CLI is very restrictive. 


### Describe the solution you'd like
Developers should be able to pass custom arguments to ng serve command. Classic example as follows. Our current project has so many API endpoints like DEV1, DEV2... SIT1, SIT2, SVP to PROD. So with previous NG CLI versions we had our custom proxy conf file which reads an argument like  endpoint and then proxy to the correct API endpoint. But with new limitation we are unable to do that.
E.g. 
`ng serve --ssl true --proxy-config proxy.conf.js --endpoint sit1`

proxy conf.

```
const ENDPOINTS = {
	local: {
		endpoint: 'https://localhost:9443',
		mockEam: true
	},
	dev1: {
		endpoint: 'https:/dev.test.com.au',
                autoRewrite: true,
                changeOrigin: true,
		proxy: false
	},
	sit1: {
		endpoint: 'https://dev.test.com.au',
                autoRewrite: true,
                changeOrigin: true,
                proxy: true
	},
	uat1: {
		endpoint: 'https://uat.test.com.au'
	},
	svp1: {
		endpoint: 'https://svp.test.com.au',
		proxy: true
	}
};
```


### Describe alternatives you've considered
Can't think of any alternatives other than modify the endpoint manually every time which is a poor developer experience.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Enable custom arguments in serve command" (#13937)

Issues.Title: fix(@schematics/angular): remove baseUrl from universal tsconfig
Issues.Body:
The baseUrl is used for non relative module imports, and we should always use the baseUrl set in the workspace tsconfig. When having path mappings set at workspace level and setting a `baseUrl` in the server tsconfig, this paths will no longer work as paths mapping as relative to the baseUrl.

Fixes #13935
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(@schematics/angular): remove baseUrl from universal tsconfig" (#13938)

Issues.Title: ng add @nguniversal/express-engine doesn't work with lib
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) ``` - [ ] new - [ ] build - [ ] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [x] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ``` ### Is this a regression? no ### Description running `ng add @nguniversal/express-engine --clientProject projectName` generates `tsconfig.server.json` which has `"baseUrl": "."` that broke the `paths` from the parent `tsconfig.json` the `paths` option is used when generating a library so that the project reads the complied code from dist and works normally ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction Reproduction repo https://github.com/robertIsaac/ng-lib-ssr generated as followed ``` ng new lib-ssr // commit #1 initial commit cd lib-ssr // works fine from localhost:4200 ng add @nguniversal/express-engine --clientProject lib-ssr // commit #2 add ssr npm run build:ssr && npm run serve:ssr // works fine from localhost:4000 ng g library lib // commit #3 add lib ng b lib // build the library to start using it // import LibModule from app.module and use compoennt in app.compoennt // commit #4 "use lib component inside the project" npm start // works fine from lcoalhost:4200 and shows "lib works!" npm run build:ssr && npm run serve:ssr or just ng run lib-ssr:server:production // will throw the error ``` ## üî• Exception or Error 

ERROR in src\app\app.module.ts(13,5): Error during template compile of 'AppModule'
  Could not resolve lib relative to [object Object]..
src/app/app.module.ts(5,25): error TS2307: Cannot find module 'lib'.
## üåç Your Environment 

     _                      _                 ____ _     ___
    / \   _ __   __ _ _   _| | __ _ _ __     / ___| |   |_ _|

  / ___ \| | | | (_| | |_| | | (_| | |      | |___| |___ | |
 /_/   \_\_| |_|\__, |\__,_|_|\__,_|_|       \____|_____|___|
                |___/

Issues.Title: SchemaValidationException errors cannot be confirmed with instanceof
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report
```
- [ ] bug report
- [x] feature request for Schematics
```
### Description
`InvalidInputOptions` and `SchemaValidationException` are difficult to catch due to https://github.com/Microsoft/TypeScript/issues/13965

A solution is outlined in https://github.com/Microsoft/TypeScript/issues/13965#issuecomment-278570200 which would enable us to catch `SchemaValidationExceptions` with the `instanceof` operator and write more robust/intuitive code.

## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction
Attempt to `instanceof schema.SchemaValidationException` an `InvalidInputOptions` exception, and bear witness to the falsey response.

Issues.Title: Adding schematics short alias to angular.json
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ Feature request


### Command (mark with an `x`)
```
- [ ] new
- [ ] build
- [ ] serve
- [ ] test
- [ ] e2e
- [ X] generate
- [ ] add
- [ ] update
- [ ] lint
- [ ] xi18n
- [ ] run
- [ ] config
- [ ] help
- [ ] version
- [ ] doc
```

### Description

`ng g @someorg/somepackage:some-long-schematic my-name`
This is a long and tedious command.




### Describe the solution you'd like
I propose
`ng g some-schematic my-name`

With a `angular.json` containing:
```
{
   "cli": {
        "schematicsAliases": [{
             "name": "some-schematic",
             "reference": "@someorg/somepackage:some-long-schematic"
        }]
   }
//...
}
```


### Describe alternatives you've considered
List of collections where it is not necessary to provide the package name.
The ng utility would take the first schematic that is encountered in the collection list.
```
{
   "cli": {
        "defaultCollection ": ["@someorg/package1", "@otherorg/package2"]
   }
//...
}
```
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Adding schematics short alias to angular.json" (#13918)

Issues.Title: fix(bottom-sheet): unable to reopen same bottom sheet after closing via back button
Issues.Body:
**Note:** this is difficult to capture in a unit test, because it depends on things from the router and animations hence why a test has been omitted here.

Fixes not being able to reopen the same bottom sheet, if the user closed it by pressing back. The issue comes from the fact that we only consider the bottom sheet as closed when its animation completes, however that might not happen if the component is destroyed. The following changes work around the issue by completing the closing sequence on detach, rather than depending on the animation.

Fixes #15510.

Issues.Title: refactor(tree): rework to account for ivy changes
Issues.Body:
Equivalent of #15503 for the Ivy branch.

Reworks the `MatTree` and `CdkTree` components to account for some of the changes in Ivy. This includes:

* Changing the padding directive to account for a different time at which static inputs are initialized.
* Changing the toggle directive to account for inheritance of host listeners working differently.
* Switching to `Default` change detection, because the way embedded views are checked is slightly different.
* Using `descendants: true` to find the nested node outlet in order to handle a slight difference in how indirect content children are matched.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "refactor(tree): rework to account for ivy changes" (#15504)

Issues.Title: refactor(tree): rework to account for ivy changes
Issues.Body:
Reworks the `MatTree` and `CdkTree` components to account for some of the changes in Ivy. This includes:

* Changing the padding directive to account for a different time at which static inputs are initialized.
* Changing the toggle directive to account for inheritance of host listeners working differently.
* Switching to `Default` change detection, because the way embedded views are checked is slightly different.
* Using `descendants: true` to find the nested node outlet in order to handle a slight difference in how indirect content children are matched.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "refactor(tree): rework to account for ivy changes" (#15503)

Issues.Title: build: do not run dgeni with  "info" log level
Issues.Body:
With Bazel it's uncommon to print anything except failures. Currently
the Dgeni logic that runs as part of our Bazel build is the only action
that prints something for a successful build. In order to make our Bazel
output clean, we lower the log level. For debugging, it's still easy to
modify the log-level.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "build: do not run dgeni with  "info" log level" (#15512)

Issues.Title: stepper.next() with [completed] value don't behave like expected
Issues.Body:
#### What is the expected behaviour?
after finishing a step the completed value of the step is assigned to true. Calling stepper.next() will advance you to the next step.

#### What is the current behaviour?
after finishing a step the completed value of the step is assigned to true. After that stepper.next() is called and nothing happens. With a second call to this method the stepper advances. The user needs to click once, not twice.

#### What are the steps to reproduce?
https://stackblitz.com/edit/mat-horizontal-stepper-lyqe5x
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "stepper.next() with [completed] value don't behave like expected" (#15511)

Issues.Title: Material Bottom sheet does not closes properly on back button press
Issues.Body:
#### Bug: Material Bottom sheet is not closing properly when the browser or mobile back button is pressed. when we press browser or mobile back button bottom sheet closes as expected but when we try to re-open the sheet then the only overlay is being displayed without the bottom sheet.


#### What is the expected behavior?
The bottom-sheet should open properly when closed via a back button

#### What is the current behavior?
Only an overlay is being displayed when reopening sheet.

#### What are the steps to reproduce?
1. Go to https://material.angular.io/components/bottom-sheet/overview

2. Open a bottom sheet.

3. Then press browser back button

4. The bottom sheet will close now.

5. Again go-to bottom-sheet component

6. Now try to reopen the sheet.


#### What is the use-case or motivation for changing an existing behavior?


#### Which versions of Angular, Material, OS, TypeScript, browsers are affected?
AngularMaterial version:7.3.4

#### Is there anything else we should know?
![1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16730825/54489566-9bc21d00-48d3-11e9-8966-f52a0c9b21b0.PNG)
![2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16730825/54489567-9c5ab380-48d3-11e9-979e-bdee2c2f04b3.png)
![3](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16730825/54489568-9cf34a00-48d3-11e9-8e64-2df304e21100.PNG)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Material Bottom sheet does not closes properly on back button press" (#15510)

Issues.Title: feat(stepper): add the ability to control the position of the header in a horizontal stepper
Issues.Body:
Allows users to control where the header of a horizontal stepper is rendered. In some cases it might make more sense to have the buttons be under the content so that the user doesn't have to go back in the page layout in order to continue to the next step.

![example](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4450522/54489130-5b4da980-48a9-11e9-8584-0754fdf1ce3e.png)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "feat(stepper): add the ability to control the position of the header in a horizontal stepper" (#15509)

Issues.Title: fix(button-toggle): value cleared when replacing with list that still contains the selected value
Issues.Body:
In #14627 we added some logic that removes the selected button toggle from the selection when it's destroyed. In an attempt to work around a "changed after checked" error we wrapped the call in a `Promise.resolve`, however that introduced an issue where we might end up overwriting a subsequent value, if it happens immediately after a button is destroyed. These changes move some things around to ensure that we don't overwrite the user's value.

Fixes #15297.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(button-toggle): value cleared when replacing with list that still contains the selected value" (#15508)

Issues.Title: fix(slide-toggle): clear name from host node
Issues.Body: Along the same lines as #15422 and #15368. Clears the static `name` attribute from the slide toggle's host node in order to prevent both the underlying input and the host from showing up in `document.getElementsByName` or `By.name`.

Issues.Title: schematics: CSS files generated in Angular CLI project using SCSS styles
Issues.Body:
#### What is the expected behavior?
`.scss` files should be generated

#### What is the current behavior?
`.css` files are generated

#### What are the steps to reproduce?
- ng new --styles=scss material-demo
  - no routing module
- ng add @angular/material
  - select Custom theme
  - add hammerjs
  - add animations module
```
ng g @angular/material:nav 
? What should be the name of the component? nav
CREATE src/app/nav/nav.component.css (193 bytes)
CREATE src/app/nav/nav.component.html (934 bytes)
CREATE src/app/nav/nav.component.spec.ts (1061 bytes)
CREATE src/app/nav/nav.component.ts (544 bytes)
UPDATE src/app/app.module.ts (785 bytes)
```

It doesn't seem to be picking up the default style extension from the workspace.
angular.json
```js
      "schematics": {
        "@schematics/angular:component": {
          "style": "scss"
        }
      },
```

#### Which versions of Angular, Material, OS, TypeScript, browsers are affected?
```
Angular CLI: 7.3.6
Node: 10.15.3
OS: darwin x64
Angular: 7.2.9
... animations, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms
... language-service, platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic
... router

Package                           Version
-----------------------------------------------------------
@angular-devkit/architect         0.13.6
@angular-devkit/build-angular     0.13.6
@angular-devkit/build-optimizer   0.13.6
@angular-devkit/build-webpack     0.13.6
@angular-devkit/core              7.3.6
@angular-devkit/schematics        7.3.6
@angular/cdk                      7.3.4
@angular/cli                      7.3.6
@angular/material                 7.3.4
@ngtools/webpack                  7.3.6
@schematics/angular               7.3.6
@schematics/update                0.13.6
rxjs                              6.3.3
typescript                        3.2.4
webpack                           4.29.0
```
OS: macOS Mojave

#### Is there anything else we should know?
This was working in `7.0.0`.
@devversion this seems to be related to https://github.com/angular/material2/pull/15235.
